data.title: Only respond to click event, instead of both mouse down + click
Dialog to save unsaved changes for a scene shows twice
data.body:
1. Open a scene in the editor (I'm using the base 3d example.)
2. make a change.
3. click the X to close the scene window.
4. 2 Save dialogs will pop to save the scene.

Expected: Only 1 dialog should prompt the user to save the scene.

data.title: Windows editor should start maximized if exited in this state
data.body: Currently when exiting the editor in a maximized state, the window is roughly the correct size however it is not maximized and slightly smaller than it should be.

data.title: menubar does not toggle properly once opened and clicked again
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:

Open Editor.
Click the 'File' menubar widget.
The File menu widget will open.
Click the 'File' menubar widget again.
The File menu will stay open.

Expected: The file menu should close.

Every menu implementation I've seen/used will toggle the menu if the widget is clicked multiple times. This functionality should be emulated in Atomic.  

I dug around a bit but couldn't find how to fix this (though I'm really just getting my feet wet here), it might be something with turbobadger or a setting I'm missing.

data.title: Splits up AtomicEngine menu to conform with standard program menus
data.body:
Moves Quit to File menu.
all other options to the Help menu.
removes AtomicEngine from the menubar.
This format mirrors major editors (Unity, VS, etc)

Use TSLint and configure it properly for the Editor TypeScript builds
data.body:
To retain consistency across the TypeScript codebase, it would be useful to start using TSLint to check the code
https://github.com/palantir/tslint

There is also an Atom Editor plugin for it.

I've created a sample tsling.json configuration file that matches the style so far in the editor, but it should be tweaked based upon how the code should ultimately look

**tslint.json**

```
{
  "rules": {
    "class-name": true,
    "curly": false,
    "eofline": false,
    "forin": false,
    "indent": [true, 4],
    "label-position": true,
    "label-undefined": true,
    "max-line-length": false,
    "no-arg": true,
    "no-bitwise": true,
    "no-console": [true,
      "debug",
      "info",
      "time",
      "timeEnd",
      "trace"
    ],
    "no-construct": true,
    "no-debugger": true,
    "no-duplicate-key": true,
    "no-duplicate-variable": true,
    "no-empty": true,
    "no-eval": true,
    "no-imports": true,
    "no-string-literal": false,
    "no-trailing-comma": true,
    "no-trailing-whitespace": true,
    "no-unused-variable": false,
    "no-unreachable": true,
    "no-use-before-declare": true,
    "one-line": [true,
      "check-open-brace",
      "check-catch",
      "check-whitespace"
    ],
    "quotemark": [true, "double"],
    "radix": false,
    "semicolon": true,
    "triple-equals": [false, "allow-null-check"],
    "variable-name": false,
    "whitespace": [true,
      "check-branch",
      "check-decl",
      "check-operator",
      "check-separator"
    ]
  }
}
```

data.title: Multi Language Templates for #495
data.body:
This provides a dropdown on the new project / clone example project dialog to specify which source code language to generate the project for.  Associated with #495.

Notable changes:
- Added a dropdown to the create project dialog that is fed from entries in the JSON configuration for the template
- created a JSON configuration file for the standard templates (2d, 3d, empty)
- updated the JSON configuration file for the examples to use the new structure 
- specified that the Roboman3d example can have a JavaScript and TypeScript target
- created TypeScript versions of the 3 standard project types
- modified the way that the templates get copied.  Now, instead of just the resources folder getting copied, the entire folder gets copied and a cache folder generated.  The .atomic file then gets renamed
- More languages can easily be added by just updating the template configuration in the JSON (ie, C#, C++, etc)
- The TypeScript example projects store the .ts files alongside the .js files instead of storing them in a separate source directory.  When the TypeScript gets compiled, it will just overwrite the .js file of the same name.

Questions:
There are a few things that may need to be discussed
1) the *.d.ts files for the typescript examples are just stored in the template.  Would it be better to auto-update them on editor build?
2) the editor currently doesn't view .ts files, just .js files.  When the editor pulls in the Chromium framework, would it be possible to display different languages or should the editor go ahead and allow display of .ts files as is?
3) Once number 2 is resolved, that opens up the ability to have the New Component/New Script menu item generate a stub file in the appropriate language.
4) Is there a format for the .atomic project file?  I would like to store the source code language for the project in that file so other elements of the editor can get at it.

data.title: Adding Node.js license (with deps), Jake, and TypeScript licenses
Provide a way to jump to objects referenced in the inspector
data.body: For example when a static model is selected, clicking on the name of the applied material- or on a button next to the name of the material- exposes and highlights the material in the project hierarchy.

data.title: Fix compilation on VS2015 Update 1
Be able to specify source code language for new project and examples
data.body:
When specifying a new project, a dropdown of available languages for the project type should be available to select which project template to use.  This should also apply to the Examples so that if an example is written in multiple languages, it is possible to select which version to use.

This will then clone the appropriate project template/example into the path the user specifies.

data.title: Fix when sometimes captured widget wasn't released.
data.body: There's also a fix for #491, added "Material" label

data.title: Try closing current project automatically for user when open a new project
data.body:
- The "Please close the current project before opening new one" dialog becoming annoying when you switching project a lot
- And it took at least 7 mouse clicks to open a project
- Now it's 2 mouse clicks.

data.title: When there is a material or shader issue, use an obvious default
data.body:
Currently when an object is rendered in the editor with a material that has something wrong it appears to be rendered with at least some values inherited from the last rendered object. For example if a diffuse texture is missing, the last set diffuse texture is used. On some objects this may not be obvious as the missing settings may still fit in the scene.

Ideally, a standard "something is wrong" set of render settings should be used when something is incorrectly set up. Either a bright untextured material with a solid colour vertex unlikely to be used in a normal object (magenta, lime green) or a simple unlit diffuse material with a material that includes text indicating what is wrong.

Multiple examples are on the way as well.
